text: yo yo yo <!channel> , our monthly Diversity Inclusion meeting is in about 3 minutes in Courtyard! I will be leading this month's meeting and have a (hopefully) interesting activity planned for us to get the ball rolling. If you have the time, you should come!
<!channel> changed to Glass... it appears as though there is an important meeting in Courtyard and it looks like it isn't ending anytime soon.
<@U0B9N0HF0|rob> uploaded a file: <https://uncorked.slack.com/files/rob/F2X8Y4V6V/slack_for_ios_upload.jpg|Slack for iOS Upload>

For our diversity meeting we talked about the different areas on the left and how we feel uncorked is doing in diversity (actually having employees who are diverse in those areas) and awareness (understanding the different perspectives associated with those areas). The top right quadrant is the goal. But we had quite a few items in the lower left quadrant. We came to the conclusion that, while it is difficult to affect change on the x axis (though that doesn't mean we should stop trying), it is up to us to improve the y axis. The three areas we could really improve upon were age, religion, and politics. Curious to hear what people have to say about those particular areas. We thought that the best way to improve upon that is to make dialogue about those areas more open.

i have found religion to be oppressively disliked in tech. something about science and religion struggle together, for most folks anyway. my mom's dad was a minister in the first assemblies of god church (southern tent revival like roots) and i spent my pre-teen thursday nights in a choice practice room at university presbyterian church in seattle b/c my mom couldn't afford to pay a babysitter when she had to practice. she sang three services every sunday in a very musically advanced church that had seven services, radio broadcast, and paid soloists. i choose to be baptized (as presbyterian) as a teenager, by my grandfather to declare myself as a Christian believer. i went to catholic school from 2nd-5th grade, and church until high school, i think. then college and tech happened and find myself adrift in my beliefs but moreover adrift in my conviction that society has suitably replaced religion with value systems that take precedence over personal gain. put another way, some of the attributes i think of as critical to my integrity and priorities stem from religious indoctrination, despite "canceling the magazine subscription" somewhere around 20 years ago.

So well said, John. Thank you for sharing. I actually said "wow" out loud after reading this. I couldn't agree more that our backgrounds (from various POVs) influence our perceptions and views of the world.
Which is something we talked about quite a bit in our meeting.
also im getting old and i dont like trump.
